Duke Leto Atreides is assigned by the Padishah Emperor Shaddam IV to replace Baron Vladimir Harkonnen as the fiefholder of Arrakis, a harsh desert planet and the sole source of 'spice'.
'Spice' is the sole source found on Arrakis, a harsh desert planet.
Spacing Guild Navigators have the ability to guide starships to traverse space instantaneously and safely with the help of 'spice'.
The Padishah Emperor Shaddam IV assigns Duke Leto Atreides to replace Baron Vladimir Harkonnen as the fiefholder of Arrakis.
Baron Vladimir Harkonnen is the current fiefholder of Arrakis.
Duke Leto Atreides belongs to House Atreides.
Baron Vladimir Harkonnen belongs to House Harkonnen.
The mysterious natives of Arrakis are known as the Fremen.

Leto's concubine Lady Jessica is an acolyte of the Bene Gesserit, a sisterhood with advanced physical and mental abilities. As part of their centuries-long breeding program, they instructed Jessica to bear a daughter whose son would become the Kwisatz Haderach.
The Bene Gesserit's centuries-long breeding program involved instructing Jessica to bear a daughter whose son would become the Kwisatz Haderach.
The Bene Gesserit breeding program aimed to create a messianic superbeing with the clairvoyance necessary to guide humanity to a better future.
Jessica, as part of the Bene Gesserit sisterhood, teaches her son Paul Bene Gesserit disciplines.
Leto's concubine Lady Jessica is also a member of the Bene Gesserit sisterhood.
Paul, Leto's son, was born as a result of Jessica disobeying the Bene Gesserit and bearing him instead of fulfilling their breeding program.
Paul is trained by Leto's aides, Duncan Idaho and others.
Jessica, Paul's mother, confides in Duncan about troubling visions of the future.
The Reverend Mother and Imperial Truthsayer Gaius Helen Mohiam subjects Paul to a deadly gom jabbar test.
The Reverend Mother and Imperial Truthsayer Gaius Helen Mohiam assess Paul's humanity and impulse control through the gom jabbar test.
At a meeting on Giedi Prime, Mohiam insists Baron Harkonnen spare Paul and Jessica in his coup, to which he duplicitously agrees.
The natives of Arrakis, the principal stronghold on the planet, revere Paul and Jessica due to beliefs sown by the Bene Gesserit centuries earlier.
House Atreides arrives at Arrakeen, the principal stronghold on Arrakis.
plan to marry one of Emperor Shaddam's daughters to avert potential civil war arising from the Emperor's betrayal
appoints his nephew Rabban to oversee Arrakis and orders him to restart spice production to recoup the invasion's cost
encountered Stilgar's Fremen tribe, including Chani, the young woman from Paul's visions
Fremen warrior Jamis challenges Paul to a ritual duel to the death, which Paul wins
Choreographer Milena Sidorova portrays the Baron's human-spider hybrid pet via motion capture.
Sacrifices himself, enabling Paul and Jessica's escape from Sardaukar soldiers armed with a lasgun
Tries to escape but is caught and mortally wounded, lures sandworm to her location to devour herself and the Sardaukar
Lured by Kynes, who is mortally wounded, in order to devour herself and the Sardaukar
Provides lenience towards Paul and Jessica when they encounter his Fremen tribe

Following the publication of Frank Herbert's novel Dune in 1965, it was considered as having potential for a possible film adaptation. Since 1971, various producers have held film adaptation rights for the novel.
Attempts to make an adaptation based on the book were considered to be 'unfilmable' due to its breadth of content.
The book's status among fans meant that deviations without strong justification could potentially harm the film's reputation.
Paramount later cancelled the project in March 2011, as they could not come to key agreements, with their rights reverting to Rubinstein.
with their rights reverting to Rubinstein.
In 2011, Mary Parent and her producer partner Cale Boyter acquired adaptation rights for Dune.
Legendary obtained film and TV rights for Dune in November 2016.

Canadian filmmaker Denis Villeneuve expressed interest in the project in September 2016, saying that "a longstanding dream of mine is to adapt Dune, but it's a long process to get the rights, and I don't think I will succeed". By December, Villeneuve was in talks with the studio to direct the film.
Parent hired Villeneuve after hearing him describe his vision for the film.
Villeneuve chose to complete Arrival (2016) and Blade Runner 2049 (2017) first.
He chose to spend more time to develop Dune and co-write it himself, employing his past experience directing science fiction films during development.
Villeneuve signed on to direct the film by January 2017, approximately one week after earning a nomination Academy Award for Best Director for Arrival.

French-Canadian director Denis Villeneuve signed on to adapt Frank Herbert's seminal 1965 novel Dune in early 2017, with Legendary Entertainment and Universal Pictures co-producing and distributing. Villeneuve's previous collaborators on Arrival and Blade Runner 2049 returned for Dune, including film editor Joe Walker, production designer Patrice Vermette, visual effects supervisor Paul Lambert, sound designer and editor Theo Green, and special effects supervisor Gerd Nefzer.
Some of Villeneuve's previous collaborators on Arrival and Blade Runner 2049 returned for Dune.
French-Canadian director Denis Villeneuve signed on to adapt Frank Herbert's seminal 1965 novel Dune in early 2017, with Legendary Entertainment and Universal Pictures co-producing and distributing.
Legendary Entertainment and Universal Pictures co-produced and distributed Dune, with French-Canadian director Denis Villeneuve adapting Frank Herbert's seminal 1965 novel.

Film editor Joe Walker and production designer Patrice Vermette returned to work on Dune with French-Canadian director Denis Villeneuve, following their collaborations on Arrival and Blade Runner 2049 respectively.

Visual effects supervisor Paul Lambert and special effects supervisor Gerd Nefzer both worked on Dune with French-Canadian director Denis Villeneuve, having previously collaborated with him on Blade Runner 2049.
Villeneuve stated that his goal was to adapt the novel into a two-part film series in March 2018.
Villeneuve secured a two-movie deal with Warner Bros. Pictures in the same style as the two-part adaptation of Stephen King's It in 2017 and in 2019.
The two-part adaptation of Stephen King's It in 2017 and in 2019.

edge: Villeneuve felt that the novel was too large and complex for one because of its complexity.
The production of the first film and new production deals were made to start production for the second.
Eric Roth was hired to co-write the screenplay in April.
Legendary CEO Joshua Grode affirmed that the studio planned on making a sequel.
Villeneuve completed a first draft of the script by May 2018.
The fourth draft of the screenplay, submitted in July, would cover the first half of the events from the novel.
Though later in September, Jon Spaihts was hired as co-writer alongside Roth and Villeneuve.
The team minimized incorporating elements inspired from Arab and Islamic culture as they became integrated into the world, resulting in the need to "invent more"

Roth stated that the team minimized incorporating [specific elements] as he felt Arab culture became integrated into the world, resulting in the need to 'invent more and borrow less' due to potentially overemphasizing them.
Roth felt that Arab culture became integrated into the world.

When writing his script, Villeneuve chose not to take inspiration from Lynch's Dune. He described his reaction to the film as being 'half-satisfied' and felt he would make the film with a 'different sensibility'. Villeneuve's love for Dune allowed him to focus on his own vision, and he compared his experience of making the film to archaeology, describing the process as 'going back in time and finding those images mixed with emotions, and bringing them back to life'.
Villeneuve chose not to take inspiration from Lynch's Dune. He affirmed his respect for Lynch and the film, but felt he would make the film with a 'different sensibility'.
Villeneuve chose not to incorporate concepts Jodorowsky envisioned for his Dune film, as he felt it would be 'very presumptuous and arrogant'.
In adapting the book for a contemporary audience, Villeneuve considered his screenplay 'a coming-of-age story, but also a call for action for the youth'

node_2: capitalism and exploitation of natural resources
edge: Villeneuve considered the book's social commentary regarding capitalism and the exploitation of natural resources such as oil

Villeneuve wanted to recreate the experience he had felt when he initially read the book as a teen by focusing on Paul and Jessica's relationship as the main focus of the story and giving them a secret hand gesture language they could use to communicate silently to each other

The inclusion of the informative holographic filmbook videos for Paul was adapted from the book, with Villeneuve wanting it to convey Paul's 'appetite for learning' and his desire to learn about the Arrakis and Fremen culture'

node_2: villeneuve's dream list for paul atreides
edge: Chalamet was the ideal choice for the role due to his ability to portray an 'old soul in the body of a teenager.'
Chalamet was chosen from individual castings, and Villeneuve admitted that he had no alternate choices in mind.
Ferguson entered negotiations to play the role of Lady Jessica, which she initially dismissed due to similarities with her Mission: Impossible character.

node_2: villeneuve's ideas and reading the book
edge: Ferguson was convinced after hearing Villeneuve's ideas and reading the book, enjoying the 'simplicity of wanting to save something you have created and all of these shades.'
Ferguson was already confirmed for the role of Lady Jessica by January 2019.
Compiled over 30–50 audition tapes from actors for Villeneuve to decide from when casting secondary roles.
Bautista was offered the role of Glossu Rabban following a phone call from Villeneuve.
Villeneuve contacted Bautista first, as he is an avid fan of Villeneuve and wanted to contact him.
Villeneuve wanted Stellan Skarsgård to portray Baron Vladimir Harkonnen as he had found Skarsgård intimidating.
Villeneuve personally contacted Charlotte Rampling in order to portray Gaius Helen Mohiam, who accepted as she enjoyed Villeneuve's work.
Isaac contacted Villeneuve about starring in the film once he heard it was in development. Villeneuve cast him as Duke Leto, with Isaac commenting the role suited him physically.
Zendaya auditioned for the role of Chani alongside five other actresses. She was chosen as she was considered to have the best performance with Chalamet.

In the next month, Javier Bardem was cast as Stilgar in Denis Villeneuve's adaptation of Dune. Villeneuve directly called Bardem and offered him the role, as he wanted to portray Stilgar comparing it to his personal love for Aragorn in The Lord of the Rings.
Josh Brolin was cast as Gurney Halleck in Denis Villeneuve's adaptation of Dune. Brolin amusingly commented that he pretended to read the script prior to accepting the role.

Jason Momoa was cast as Duncan Idaho in Denis Villeneuve's adaptation of Dune. He received his casting call while snowboarding down a mountain and later contacted Villeneuve on a Skype call to confirm his involvement.
David Dastmalchian was cast as Piter de Vries in Denis Villeneuve's adaptation of Dune. He accepted the role without reading the script due to his confidence in Villeneuve.
Stephen McKinley Henderson joined Denis Villeneuve's adaptation of Dune in March. Maisler chose Henderson after admiring his work in New York theaters.

Denis Villeneuve's adaptation of Dune was negotiating with Chang Chen for a role in March. Maisler curated a list of the 'most talented' Chinese actors for the role of Dr. Yueh, and after initial difficulties contacting Chen, they eventually contacted his manager in China.
Denis Villeneuve's adaptation of Dune chose Benjamin Clementine as the Herald of the Change after Maisler enjoyed his performance in the Tiny Desk Concerts.
Duncan-Brewster auditioned for the role in London through Jina Jay, a casting director working with Maisler at the time, saying that she 'exudes an intelligence and a power and an inner strength'.
When Maisler presented a shortlist for potential cast members, Villeneuve selected Duncan-Brewster.
The idea to change Kynes' gender was suggested by Jon Spaihts, which Villeneuve promptly accepted.
According to Duncan-Brewster, Villeneuve opted for the change as he felt it was not necessary to adhere to all of the elements in the book in order to remain faithful to the character's nature.
The set design was done by production designer Patrice Vermette.
Vermette based the set design for Dune by the need 'to ground the story into realistic settings to help the audience believe in the extraordinary elements'.
Prior to the creation of any sets or visual effects, Villeneuve and a group of specific people, worked together to define the visual language for the film.
Vermette created a 'visual bible' to guide the development of set design and keep it consistent with the film's visual effects design.
The book gives a lot of clues or cues that will help you navigate it to design things, but it's quite nonspecific,
The team's early mood boards for the visual language of the film consisted of Mesopotamian ziggurat architecture and Egyptian references,
The team's early mood boards for the visual language of the film consisted of World War II bunkers, Brazilian and Soviet brutalist architecture,
The team's early mood boards for the visual language of the film consisted of minimalist megastructures and dams designed by Superstudio,
Imagery of glaciers taking over mountains was referenced in the team's early mood boards for the visual language of the film along with Mesopotamian ziggurat architecture,
The design for the ornithopters was conceived by Villeneuve.
Villeneuve and storyboard artist Sam Hudecki conceived the design for the ornithopters.
Villeneuve wanted the ornithopter to resemble a dragonfly.
Villeneuve wanted the ornithopter to resemble a helicopter.
Villeneuve wanted the ornithopter to be realistic.
Villeneuve wanted the ornithopter to adhere to basic laws of science.
Villeneuve perceived the Dune world as retro-futuristic and analog.
Villeneuve wanted the cockpits to be designed so that the actors could see the landscape.
Two functional ornithopter models, 48- and 75-feet long, were created for filming.
The ornithopter models had operable doors.
The ornithopter models had interior cockpit areas.
Cranes were used to make the ornithopter models fly.

Vermette sought to give Caladan 'a feeling of melancholia' and identified forests containing Norwegian pines and dramatic coastal mountain ranges as defining features, while also comparing it to the end of a cycle or the beginning of a new one.
The interior sets of Caladan were inspired by medieval Japanese aesthetics, particularly that of Paul's training room, containing intricate screens and diffused lighting.
The original design for the sandworm was deemed 'prehistoric'.
The sandworm's skin texture was based on tree bark and mud flats.

node_2: deity in the world of the fremen
edge: Vermette spoke of the challenges involved in creating the set designs used for the sandworms, stating 'It was a creature that commanded respect, and it's almost seen as a deity in the world of the Fremen. So that's why the first time you see the depiction of the sand worm on the mural, it's presented with sun coming out of its mouth'.

Vermette called Arrakeen the biggest residency ever built by humankind and described it as a colonial entity that took over the planet for the exploitation of spice, in reference to Arrakis's climate.
The design for Arrakeen was influenced by the book's description of Arrakis's climate, which revolves around spice.
Vermette designed the city in a 'rock bowl' shape to protect its infrastructure from sandworms.
The walls of Arrakeen were thickened to make the interiors cooler, in order to protect them from sandworms and high wind speeds.
The design team was inspired by WWII bunkers while creating Arrakeen's infrastructure.
The design team drew inspiration from both bunkers and Mayan temples while creating Arrakeen's infrastructure.
The design team was also inspired by Brazilian modernism while creating Arrakeen's infrastructure.
Vermette compared the depiction of Fremen history and culture in the mural to that of a church. This was done by envisioning Fremen artists doing so.
Agriculturally controlled sand was placed on the ground while filming took place during Budapest's raining season.
The circular dome for the environmental lab had spokes created by a special kind of cloth fabric, which provided proper lighting for the act and gave an illusion of shadows.
The practical set was the environmental lab in which Sardaukar soldiers descend from the air.
Both Arrakis and Caladan are planets in the fictional universe of Dune, as depicted in the film. They have a relationship as they both appear in the same context.
Both Arrakis and Giedi Prime are planets in the fictional universe of Dune, as depicted in the film. They have a relationship as they both appear in the same context.

Denis Villeneuve, the director of the film, wanted the costumes to have a connection to history and avoid traditional futuristic views in science fiction films. This shows that the costumes are related to Villeneuve's vision for the film.

Jacqueline West, the costume designer for the film, performed psychological studies of characters and associated their houses with historical symbolic analogs to facilitate her costume design process. This demonstrates a connection between West and the costumes.
West associated the Fremen with the French Resistance when designing the costumes. This indicates a relationship between the Fremen and the French Resistance.
West associated the Sardaukar with the Nazis when designing the costumes. This implies a connection between the Sardaukar and the Nazis.
West took primary inspiration from the Middle Ages to envision what it would look like in the future. This shows a relationship between the Middle Ages and the future.
West took inspiration from Giotto when designing the costumes. This indicates a connection between Giotto and the costumes.
West also took inspiration from Francisco Goya when designing the costumes. This implies a relationship between Francisco Goya and the costumes.
West also emulated styles from Caravaggio when designing the costumes. This shows a connection between Caravaggio and the costumes.
West also took inspiration from British art historian John Berger when designing the costumes. This indicates a connection between John Berger and the costumes.
West also emulated styles from Balenciaga when designing the costumes. This demonstrates a relationship between Balenciaga and the costumes.
West also emulated styles from the Bedouin when designing the costumes. This indicates a connection between the Bedouin and the costumes.
West also emulated styles from the Tuareg people when designing the costumes. This shows a relationship between the Tuareg people and the costumes.
costumes were based on tarot cards
costumes were based on tarot cards and chess pieces

The Atreides-Harkonnen feud is similar to a real Greek and Roman tragedy, which inspired West's idea for the stillsuit's design as a flexible and comfortable suit that accurately represents the book.
West dyed the gauze for Fremen cloth in desert colors, which was inspired by the sand and rocks in Jordanian filming locations.
West cited Lawrence of Arabia (1962) as an inspiration for costume diversity, which may have contributed to the design of the stillsuit.
West cited Doctor Zhivago (1965) as further inspirations for costume diversity, which may have influenced the stillsuit's design.
West also cited Fahrenheit 451 (1966) as further inspirations for costume diversity, possibly related to the stillsuit's design.
The stillsuits used over 250 times in Jordan were designed with 'micro-sandwiches' of acrylic fibers and porous cottons, which absorb moisture and allow actors to remain cool inside the suits.
Zippers and buttons were not used in the stillsuit's design as they were deemed 'archaic'.
Wadi Rum in Jordan served as a double for Arrakis, the desert planet in Dune.
Liwa Oasis in the United Arab Emirates was used as a backdrop for Arrakis, especially for the heat shelters of the Fremens.
The rock formations in Rub' al Khali desert functioned as the heat shelters for the Fremen people on Arrakis.
Stadlandet, Norway stood in for Caladan, another planet featured in the story.

Used 'sandscreens' for filming scenes in Arrakis and Arrakeen, which involved using sand-colored backgrounds that matched the establishing desert shots intended for backgrounds. This was a visual effects technique utilized by Paul Lambert while working on Dune.

node_2: approximately 18 tons of sand and dust
edge: Used approximately 18 tons of sand and dust while working on Dune.
The sandworms were created through CGI.
The VFX team found a lot of difficulty in deciding how the sandworm would move.
The team spent over a year in figuring out the movements of the sandworm, and researched the body movements of various animals, such as worms and snakes.
The sand ripples created by the worms were inspired by implicit visual cues of the shark from Jaws (1975).
Gerd Nefzer designed a vibrating 8x8 foot steel plate and placed it under the sand. This resulted in the formation of various patterns, used to signify an approaching sandworm.

node_2: sandworms breaking the surface in the desert
edge: The team initially considered using rigged explosives to capture the motion of the sandworms breaking the surface in the desert, but rejected the idea as this was impractical to perform in the Middle East.

node_2: sand emulating the motion of water
edge: Instead, they used the Houdini software to have sand emulate the motion of water.

Villeneuve did not want the associated sound design to appear as a studio production. Sound designers Mark Mangini and Theo Green used a "fake documentary realism" approach to capture natural sounds and manipulate them for use in the film, such as recording the sounds of shifting sands in Death Valley using hydrophones.
The Montreal VFX supervisor Brian Connor created a digital Arrakeen space port, while the Vancouver team simulated explosions.
The Montreal and Vancouver facilities of DNEG were used for the Arrakeen invasion sequence. It involved combining practical and digital effects.
The Vancouver team simulated explosions.

Lambert created the Holtzman shields' visual effects.
Lambert combined past and future frames after experimenting with various visual filters on an action sequence from Seven Samurai (1954), resulting in a 'shimmering' look Villeneuve approved.

Hans Zimmer affirmed he would be scoring Dune near the start of the film's production in March 2019.
Zimmer previously worked with Villeneuve on Blade Runner 2049 (2017).
Zimmer rejected director Christopher Nolan's request to compose the score for his then-upcoming film Tenet (2020), citing his personal love for the book.
Hans Zimmer spent a week in a Utah desert to incorporate its sounds into the score.
The House Atreides theme includes bagpipes, which was suggested as Villeneuve's idea of something 'ancient and organic'.
Hans Zimmer found 30 bagpipe players around Edinburgh during the COVID-19 pandemic and recorded them playing in a church.
The music was performed using an eclectic set of instruments, including some created specifically for the soundtrack.
Additional music was composed by Steve Mazzaro and David Fleming, both of whom worked in collaboration with Zimmer to keep his pieces on theme.

The film surpassed its projected opening weekend estimates of $30–35 million.

Dune had the best opening of Villeneuve's career.

This visually thrilling adaptation, based on the epic science fiction novel by Frank Herbert, tells the story of Paul Atreides (Timothée Chalamet), a brilliant and young prince, as he leads his tribe in a fight for survival against horrible sandworms and traitorous nobles.
The popular review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes has given the film Dune a positivity rating of 83% based on 514 reviews by film critics.
The movie adaptation of Dune, directed by Denis Villeneuve, is largely faithful to Frank Herbert's classic novel of the same name.

node_2: weighted average score of 74 out of 100
edge: Metacritic, a website that aggregates film reviews from critics around the world, has given Dune a weighted average score of 74 out of 100 based on 68 reviews.
Audiences who saw the movie Dune at its premiere rated it with an average grade of 'A-' on an A+ to F scale.
The movie Dune is an adaptation of the popular science fiction novel by Frank Herbert, published in 1965.
As of October 2021, over 83% of the reviews on Rotten Tomatoes for the movie Dune have been positive.
Metacritic's assessment of Dune is that it has received 'generally favorable reviews.'

According to Rotten Tomatoes, the consensus for the movie Dune is: 'Dune occasionally struggles with its unwieldy source material, but those issues are largely overshadowed by the scope and ambition of this visually thrilling adaptation.'

node_2: brilliant and young prince paul atreides
edge: In the movie Dune, Timothée Chalamet plays the role of a brilliant and young prince named Paul Atreides.

node_2: science fiction novel by frank herbert
edge: The movie Dune is based on the science fiction novel of the same name, written by Frank Herbert and published in 1965.
The movie adaptation of Dune is an epic science fiction film directed by Denis Villeneuve.

Justin Chang, from the Los Angeles Times, preferred David Lynch's style over Villeneuve's style in terms of having 'feverish, pustular imagery'. However, Chang still praised Villeneuve's production values as being monochromatic.
Justin Chang deemed the ending to be 'abrupt, unsatisfying'. No other reviewers commented on this aspect.

node_2: tension regarding anticipation of action sequences
edge: Justin Chang mentioned that the plot had tension regarding anticipation of action sequences, which he thought were directed well.

node_2: increased role of women in the story
edge: Justin Chang praised the plot for increasing the role of women in the story.

Leah Greenblatt mentioned that Dune had little exposition, while Manohla Dargis opined that Villeneuve had attempted to be faithful to the source material but also felt that Villeneuve was trying to satisfy the demands of the contemporary film industry.
Leah Greenblatt highlighted Chalamet and Isaac's performances in her review, while Manohla Dargis admired the production values and worldbuilding in hers.
Leah Greenblatt did not appreciate the jokes in her review.

Manohla Dargis opined that Villeneuve had attempted to be faithful to the source material and felt that the pacing was appropriate to establish the latter, while Justin Chang appreciated the production values and worldbuilding.
Owen Gleiberman's review in Variety labeled the use of 'Part I' in the film's title as presumptuous, comparing it to how other film franchises advertise future installments.
Owen Gleiberman in his review for Variety stated that the extensive focus on worldbuilding in 'Dune' had undermined the storytelling.
Owen Gleiberman's review in Variety used the term 'presumptuous' to describe the use of 'Part I' in the film's title.
Gleiberman mentioned in his review for Variety that as the movie begins to run out of tricks, it turns woozy and amorphous, disengaging him from the story.
Gleiberman also mentioned in his review for Variety that the spectacles, including the sandworm and ornithopter sequences, disengaged him from the story.
Steve Pond in his review for TheWrap referred to the film's dark tone as a tonal deviation but also allowed it to be 'giant mood piece that can be exhilarating in its dark beauty'.
Pond appreciated the production design and scope as positive elements in his review for TheWrap.
Pond enjoyed the action sequences on Arrakis in his review for TheWrap.
Hadadi's review in Vulture noted that the use of 'Part I' in the film's title remained consistent with its darker tone.

Hadadi criticized the way the film flattened the cultural and religious complexities of the book and opted for a more generic portrayal of people of color without specific representation from Middle Eastern or North African (MENA) actors.

Some commentators perceived the film to have neglected and appropriated Arabian and Islamic elements, reducing them to 'exotic aesthetics' and 'broad abstractions', leading to accusations of Orientalism.
Serena Rasoul, founder of Muslim Casting, wanted more representation for MENA actors but acknowledged the film's overall diversity. However, she labelled the lack of MENA actors an 'erasure'.

Ali Karjoo-Ravary, an Assistant Professor of Islamic Studies at Bucknell University, felt that the casting of African actors excluded MENA actors and that characters portrayed by African people felt 'ultimately empty' as they had died or were not as developed as Paul and Lady Jessica.
Dune was nominated for ten Academy Awards in recognition of its artistic and technical merits.
In the 94th Academy Awards ceremony, Dune won six prestigious awards in various categories, including Best Original Score, Best Cinematography, and Best Production Design.

node_2: nominated for three golden globe awards
edge: Along with the Academy Awards, Dune also received nominations in three categories at the 79th Golden Globe Awards.
At the same awards ceremony where it was also nominated, Dune took home the award for Best Original Score - Motion Picture.

node_2: nominated for eleven british academy film awards
edge: The British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) also recognized Dune's excellence by nominating it in eleven different categories.

node_2: won five british academy film awards
edge: At the 75th edition of the BAFTA Awards, Dune walked away with a total of five awards, including Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, and Best Original Score.

node_2: nominated for ten critics' choice movie awards
edge: Several critics' organizations also showered Dune with nominations across various categories at their annual awards events.

node_2: won three critics' choice movie awards
edge: At the 28th edition of the Critics' Choice Movie Awards, Dune received three prestigious awards for its outstanding visual effects, cinematography, and editing.

node_2: nominated for two aacta international awards
edge: The Australian Academy of Cinema and Television Arts (AACTA) recognized Dune's artistic excellence by nominating it in two different categories at the 7th edition of their awards.
In recognition of its outstanding cinematography, Dune won an award at the 7th edition of the AACTA International Awards.
The Satellite Awards, presented by the International Press Academy, also recognized Dune's artistic merits by nominating it in ten different categories.
At the 26th edition of the Satellite Awards, Dune received a total of five awards, including Best Motion Picture - Drama and Best Cinematography.
The Recording Academy also recognized Dune's exceptional musical score by nominating it in the category of Best Score Soundtrack for Visual Media.

node_2: won one hollywood music in media awards
edge: The Hollywood Music in Media Awards also recognized Dune's outstanding musical score by presenting it with an award in the category of Best Original Score - Feature Film.

node_2: nominated for four people's choice awards
edge: Several popular culture awards shows also recognized Dune's artistic excellence by nominating it in four different categories.
At the 48th edition of the People's Choice Awards, Dune won an award in recognition of its outstanding cinematography.

node_2: nominated for one screen actors guild awards
edge: The Screen Actors Guild also recognized Dune's artistic merits by nominating it in the category of Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture.
The Society of Queer Entertainment recognized Dune's artistic excellence by nominating it in three different categories at their annual awards event.
At the 36th edition of the Dorian Awards, Dune won an award in recognition of its outstanding cinematography.

The MovieGuide Awards, presented by the Christian Film & Television Commission, also recognized Dune's artistic excellence by presenting it with an award in recognition of its outstanding cinematography.

Villeneuve intended to make a two-part adaptation of the novel, and by November 2019, Jon Spaihts left his position as showrunner on Dune: Prophecy to focus on writing the sequel film.
Spaihts left his position as showrunner on Dune: Prophecy to focus on writing the sequel film.
Villeneuve intended to make a two-part adaptation of the novel, and by November 2019, Jon Spaihts left his position as showrunner on Dune: Prophecy to focus on writing the sequel film.
Additional casting lasting from March to July 2022, and concluding by January 2023.
Preliminary filming began in Italy by early July 2022, and concluded that December.
The film was released on March 1, 2024.
The world premiere took place at Odeon Luxe Leicester Square in London on February 15.
Villeneuve expressed interest in making a third film based on Dune Messiah.
The possibility for the film depended on the success of Dune: Part Two, as expressed by Villeneuve.
Spaihts also reiterated in March 2022 that Villeneuve had plans for a third film as well as the television spin-off series Dune: Prophecy.
Villeneuve declared his intentions for the film to serve as the conclusion of his Dune trilogy.
Villeneuve began developing a script by 2023.
Citing Hollywood’s tendency of focusing on release dates over quality, Villeneuve said the script was 'almost finished' but also wanted to take time to ensure his satisfaction.
Ahead of Dune: Part Two’s release, Hans Zimmer revealed he was already writing music for a third film.
